body.p: There are multiple sensors in different organ systems for detecting changes in blood pressure. This suggests that:

input.choice: (A) There are multiple feedback loops for regulating blood pressure.
(B) A control center integrates information from multiple sensors.
(C) The body changes which sensor it uses depending on the conditions the body is experiencing.
Both A and B could be correct.

feedback.p: Incorrect. While there may be different feedback loops, they would not each be totally independent, so this is not the best answer.

Incorrect. While a control center may receive input from multiple sensors, there is not just one control center for all the different organ systems involved in blood pressure homeostasis, so this is not the best answer.
Incorrect. All of the sensors would normally be functioning at the same time, even though they may provide input to different control centers.

Correct. Multiple sensors could mean there are multiple feedback loops involving different organ systems, and a single control center can be integrating information from multiple sensors. . In this way, different organ systems will interact to maintain blood pressure.

body.p: What can result from ingestion of unrestricted amounts of water?

input.choice: good health; water is good for you

feedback.p: Incorrect. Most people don’t consume enough water. However, too much of something can be as harmful as too little of it; that is why homeostasis maintains a "set point."
Incorrect. The body will have problems, but positive feedback loops will not occur; this is still a negative feedback process, but the effectors cannot keep up with the input.

Incorrect. Too much of something can be as harmful as too little of it; that is why homeostasis maintains a "set point." Too much water causes urination initially, but if the urinary system can’t process all of the fluid fast enough, the water will dilute the blood, cause parts of the body to swell, and ultimately inhibit brain function.

body.p: What can happen if cell number in a tissue is not homeostatically maintained?

feedback.p: Correct. When cells are not able to regulate homeostasis, a tumor can form.
Incorrect. An infection occurs when foreign organisms enter a tissue or cell.
Incorrect. It’s possible that too much nerve death can lead to a loss of homeostasis, but usually nerve damage occurs from a cut.
Incorrect. Apoptosis is a programmed cell death that helps maintain homeostasis.

body.p: Calcium is critical for so many body functions. Which of the following systems is not directly involved in the homeostatic maintenance of blood calcium levels?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The osteoclasts in bone, under the influence of parathyroid hormone, play a major role in the release of calcium from bone tissue.
Incorrect. The small intestine, under the influence of Vitamin D, plays a major role in the absorption of calcium from foods.

Correct. The muscular system needs calcium for contraction, but does not play a role in the maintenance of blood calcium levels. Instead, muscles play an important role in temperature homeostasis with the integumentary and cardiovascular systems.
Incorrect. The kidney, under the influence of parathyroid hormone, plays a major role in the conservation of calcium rather than excretion in urine.

body.p: As you exercise, many different body systems must work together to adjust and maintain conditions suitable for normal function. Which of the following would NOT be directly involved in the immediate adjustments needed during exercise?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The heart rate will need to adjust to provide sufficient oxygen to the skeletal muscles during exercise.
Incorrect. The sweat glands in the skin will need to adjust to help regulate body temperature during exercise.

– Correct. While the digestive system is the ultimate source of energy for exercise, increased activity is not needed during exercise and, in fact, blood flow may be diverted away from the digestive system to allow more oxygen and nutrients flow to the skeletal muscles.
Incorrect. The respiratory rate will need to adjust to provide sufficient oxygen and removal of carbon dioxide during exercise.
